https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/507575.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW, WOW, WOW!!!
This is the absolute best stuffing I have ever had. So flavorful and moist. I made a few changes but it still keeps the integrity of the original recipe. First, I left out the liver and I used sage flavored pork sausage and only a 1/2 lb. We are not big sausage fans here but still wanted to have some of the flavor. Second, I used fresh herbs and added marjoram. Fresh herbs do make a big difference. If you use fresh herbs, double the amount to = dried herbs. Third, I used 1 loaf Publix bakery Sour Dough 7 Grain bread, 1 potato roll, and 3 slices white bread. I used crust and all. I figured the grains would add a nice flavor. Fourth, I added an egg to help hold it all together. I did STUFF my turkey with this stuffing. My parents stuffed their birds and so have I. I have NEVER been sick from it. Your Stuffing must be 160*. Besides the egg, everything is already cooked and the bacteria in the turkey dies off as the bird cooks to the correct temp. I will absolutely make this again and again and again. Thanks :)

text:
This really is AWESOME stuffing!!!  I love it, and so does my whole family...the turkey gets neglected during the late night raids to the fridge for leftovers to eat this!  I have tweaked it a little, it is great like it is, but I really think my tweaks are an improvement!  #1. I bake my own bread, then cube it and toast it  a couple days before, so it can stand out to get hard. I use 1 2lb loaf of whole wheat, and 1 1 lb loaf of white wheat. I use 2 granny smith apples, fresh herbs, and A LOT more stock (Also, It is fabulous with real sage pork sausage) I will never make any other recipe for stuffing!  (my family would kill me if I did)

text:
I was a little disappointed by this after all the hype it's gotten. I followed it pretty closely, with a few alterations that were recommended by other reviewers (minor tweaks like sage sausage and Granny Smith apples instead of regular sausage and Golden Delicious, respectively), but found that I still prefer stuffing with bacon rather then sausage.

I've never added apples to my stuffing before, however, so I am happy to have walked away from this with the discovery of what kind of great flavor apples can add to your stuffing.

This is a wonderful recipe but I prefer my family's.

text:
I have never made stuffing from scratch. This was the best! My guests loved it. I have to be honest, I still made Stove Top as a back up but no one touched it. This recipe is definitly a keeper!
I did change a few things like others said. I used 1C of chicken stock, used fresh herbs, omitted turkey liver, used pork sausage instead of turkey sausage and used a granny smith apple. 
I deep fry my turkeys so I used a 9x13 dish for the stuffing. Reheated at 350 for 30 min covered and then another 10 minutes uncovered.

text:
This is my first time leaving a review, and I just had to because I had nothing but good compliments on this stuffing! We've never made stuffing before, nor have we ever made our own Thanksgiving meal. this year was our first time, and I am SO glad I chose this recipe. As of today there is no more stuffing leftover, and in fact I wish I still had some to eat...  We kind of eyeballed the spices and adjusted other ingredients to our liking but the suggestions that turned out well were: Jimmy Dean turkey sausage, it's really yummy in the stuffing. More broth to make it more moist, especially if it's not going to be baked inside the turkey. We didn't use the liver since we were too lazy, but it still tasted great. We also used boxed stuffing as the bread since we were too busy cooking other things to make the bread, but it still tasted delicious!

text:
I figured over a thousand reviews with positive ratings couldn't be wrong and I was right!  First time branching out beyond the traditional dressing and we LOVED it!  I doubled the recipe which filled a 9x13 foil pan along with another casserole dish.  Used sourdough instead of white bread, chicken broth, regular JD sausage (plain) and a whole tube for the double batch was PLENTY so if making the regular size I'd suggest just half a tube, skipped the liver and only did 1 c onion and 3/4 c celery b/c I'm not a big fan of either (personal tastes you may want more).  Baked at 350 covered for 30, stirred, and baked for another 15 uncovered (depends on how dry your bread is).  I like my dressing with the bread crumbs intact and not mushy so the broth amount was great for me.  HIGHLY recommend this recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
OMG!!! Talking about the best dressing I've ever had!! I made it as dressing instead of stuffing and I did make a few changes because of what I had available and the preferences of my family, but I'm sure the original would have been just as good too. :)

My husband does not like fruit in his dressing and my mom can't eat fruit, so I was preparing for two separate dishes of dressing (with the fruit added at the end to the second dish before it went into the oven). The changes that I made were:

--1 and a 1/2 loaves of homemade cornbread instead of bread (I'm a southerner, got to have cornbread dressing. ;) )
--1 lb of chicken breast, cut in bite sized pieces, instead of turkey sausage (that is all I had)
--2 cups of chopped onion instead of 1 cup
--Fresh herbs instead of dried
--Chicken Stock instead of Turkey Stock (didn't have time to make the turkey stock like I had wanted)
--I did not add Turkey Liver to it because my whole family HATES livers.
--Instead of using a fresh apple, I had found this package of a mixture of dried cranberries and dried apples seasoned with cinnamon and decided to give it a shot (it worked GREAT).

There were a lot of little changes I know, but the flavors are similar, so I know the original would have been just as good. I can't wait to make this again for Christmas. Thank you SO much for my new dressing recipe.

text:
Gluten-free heaven is easy!!  Just use this recipe (the best ever!!!) but use gluten-free rice bread instead.  I'm a celiac and haven't eaten stuffing in like twenty years. I decided to try a gluten-free (tested it a week or so ago) stuffing, because my brother said "no stuffing?? you HAVE to make stuffing." I cut the cranberries to 1/2 cup (too sweet with craisins) and added more liquid. I cook all natural and mostly organic and this is the best stuffing i've EVER had!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last year as my first attempt at homemade stuffing.  This is the absolutely best stuffing I have ever had.  I did modify it a bit - I omitted the liver (personal preference), and I discovered an awesome cheat that works just as well and saves a ton of time.  I bought a bread loaf that is already seasoned for use in stuffing.  I slice it, toast slices in the toaster, then cut them into cubes while the next slices are toasting.  Much less hassle than trying to toast them on a sheet in an already much monopolized oven. As well, I could omit the herbs and spices that were already baked into the bread. This recipe was so good that I made it twice more on consecutive days afterwards in a casserole dish (just added more chicken broth than it called for) and it turned out awesome as well.  Now I'm getting ready to make it again this weekend! Happy Thanksgiving! 


UPDATE: I've made this several times since the first review, and I now only make it in a casserole dish, much like other reviewers. Getting ready to make it again this weekend!  Happy Canadian Thanksgiving!

text:
I made this for Thanksgiving and was so glad I did. Confession: I used to use a boxed stuffing. This was a huge improvement! I made just a couple of changes: Like most reviewers, I skipped the turkey liver (didn't want to deal with it, and it just didn't sound appetizing); I used about 2-3 t. each of the herbs, and I used fresh herbs; I used chicken broth instead of turkey stock - one can. I did not bake the stuffing in the bird but separate in a 13x9 pan. It was very tasty and got rave reviews. I will definitely make again next year!

text:
Excellent stuffing recipe! After reading other reviewers' comments about the stuffing being too dry, I added more chicken stock (didn't have any turkey stock, since the bird was still cooking) and put it in the slow cooker in the morning. I started it out on high for about an hour then turned it down to low and let it cook for about 4-5 hours (I followed the instructions for Slow Cooker Stuffing on this site), being sure to stir it at least once an hour so it wouldn't burn. Sure enough, it turned out extremely moist and flavorful, and my guests gave it rave reviews.

text:
WOW, this stuffing was AMAZING! I've never made stuffing before but this is what i will make from now on. I made a double batch for the first thanksgiving i ever hosted and everyone loved it. There was hardly any left.

I used white and wheat hoggie rolls for the bread and cut them into roughly 1/3 inch cubes. I toasted them the night before and let them sit out so they were very dry. I baked it for an hour at 350 degrees and stirred it after 30.

Thank you so much for this recipe!

text:
My family raved over this stuffing when I made it for Thanksgiving this year.  I used turkey sausage instead, but I think a full pound was too much for my taste.  It was too much of a meal rather than a side dish.  Also, I did not actually stuff the turkey with it, so it did not come out as sticky as I would prefer.  I recommend adding more turkey stock to it if you are not going to actually stuff the turkey with it. All in all, very very tasty!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this as a side dish. Bake in a 9 X 9 pan. If you want enough to fill a 9 X 13 pan, double the above recipe. When I double it, I do NOT double the sausage or butter, since I find it to be quite meaty/moist without doubling them. I also omit the cranberries entirely just for personal preference. The dressing will survive without the liver as well. I like to make it a day ahead & refrigerate it in a covered baking dish.

i just put this beautiful stuffing in the oven.  if it is as delicious as it smells, my family is in for a major treat.  i substituted kosher beef sausage for the pork sausage, and i used ready seasoned packaged stuffing ( not stovetop ), and didn't add more spices, as it was package ready.  i also skipped the butter, and used rendered chicken fat instead, for full flavor.  as suggested, i added more liquid ( water, as the chicken fat and seasoned stuffing have enough spice and flavor, so didn't need stock ).  hoping for an amazing turnout !

text:
I was hesitant about adding fruit to stuffing, but it turned out fabulous!  I subbed pork sausage and chicken broth because I couldn't find either.  The stuffing in the turkey came out moist and delicous.  The out-of-turkey stuffing was a little dry and slightly overdone on top, so next time I'll add extra broth and stir half way through the cooking time.  This is definately going to be a staple for our holiday meals!

userID:

Display Name:
quietlilsis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Enjoyed very much, except I really didn't follow the recipe other than as a guideline for ingredients. I used roasted garlic (loaf) bread (from Costco) and mini baguettes which I cubed and toasted. Also used spicy Italian sausage, and nixed the liver/giblets. Included apples, cranberries, and some golden raisins because I didn't have enough cranberries. Cooked sausage first, then onions. Added celery to the onions with seasonings (used fresh as many other reviews suggested). After cooking for a while, I added the cranberries, raisins, and sausage back to the onion/celery mix and continued cooking, also added some chicken stock while cooking; added peeled, chopped apples later as I didn't want them to get too soft. When cooked to my liking, I mixed everything in with the bread cubes, adding in more chicken stock...really I just eyeballed it. I made way more than twice what the recipe calls for and I'm not much for measuring so I just went by taste, looks, and consistency. The dried fruit plumped a little with the moisture of the stock; like this a lot. Oh, also, this was made separate from the turkey so was not stuffed in it, but baked on its own. Baked at 350 covered with foil for about 30 min, then removed the foil for another 15-ish minutes. The family loved it and I will be making it again next Thanksgiving. Happy cooking, happy eating!

I thought this recipe was very good. I tried it both with turkey sausage and spicy Italian sausage. Both were very tasty. userID:
575473
Display Name:
AHAMMER
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for thanksgiving for the first time this week and it was a huge success!  I changed the recipe slightly.  I only put in a couple teaspoons of minced parsley because I am not a big fan of parsley.  I also used fresh herbs so I doubled the amount that the recipe called for. I omitted the turkey liver and I used Jimmy Dean's Sage Sausage because Safeway was out my favorite italian sausage that I would have used in lieu of turkey sausage.  First let me say that Sage Sausage is fabulous!  It added a ton of flavor to the stuffing.  This recipe is especially good because you can make it ahead of time and you will be the only one that will know. (I made it two days ahead of time). I did as a previous reviewer suggested and didn't add the butter or in my case chicken stock until I was ready to bake the stuffing. It was super moist and very flavorful!  My husband and daughters don't like sweet and savory but the rest of my family does so I split the stuffing into two  casserole dishes just prior to baking.  I left one without any fruit and the second dish I added 1 fuji apple, 1 golden delicious apple with a couple generous handfuls of craisins (sweeten dried cranberries) and I was amazed at how much stuffing was consumed. This recipe is super easy to follow and lends itself to being slightly altered to please everyone! I made it for 24 servings because I have a bigger family and there is hardly any left!  Super easy and super tasty is a winning combo!

text:
This was really yummy stuffing.
With this recipe I ahd enough to stuff a 10 ound turkey and to have a good size pan full of it.
I left out the liver, didn`t think it was necessary and would not use it in future either. 
The stuffing from inside the turkey was amazing. Sooooo good. To the extra stuffing in the pan I added quite a bit of turkey stock, probably around 3 cups, so that it wouldn`t come out dry. It was really good.
I couldn`t find turkey sausage and used German "Bratwurst", tasted great.
I got a lot of compliments on the stuffing. Will make it again next Thanksgiving.
Particularly the dried cranberries in it made it different - just a nice combination of sweet and hearty.  5 stars!

text:
This is my first stuffing I ever made for Thanksgiving, and it was delicious!! Though I thought it was a bit dry. So next time, I'll be using more stock. Here are the changes I made: used white bread only, used sweet italian sausage+ removed from its casings, omitted sage (didn't have any) and liver, used dry parsley and homemade chicken stock instead of turkey stock. This is definitely a keeper!

text:
This was an awesome stuffing recipe! Thank you so much!!  Last year I tried making the slow cooker stuffing recipe from this site and it was a bust - so mushy and heavy.  I prepared this one a day in advance in a casserole dish (I don't stuff my turkey).  I put a little bit of melted butter over the top and then in the fridge.  Thanksgiving day I took it out until it was room temp, added the liquids and heated it with the lid on.  Really delicious - everyone loved it.

text:
Amazing! I stuff my turkey with herbs, apples, and onions so I had to bake this outside of the turkey for about 40 minutes covered and 15 uncovered at 350 because it seemed like a good idea at the time. In order to make sure the stuffing was extra moist, I added about a cup of Clover Hills Spiced Apple wine (I try to find an excuse to add alcohol to anything) and a little bit extra stock.  The stuffing became the focus of the meal. Alas, with ever blessing there is a slight curse; the stuffing was so good there were no leftovers.  I have some left over bread and sausage so I might make this again so I can have it with my Turkey sandwiches.

text:
Well I'm another skeptic-turned-believer. I never would have made this but the reviews were so great I had to try it. Sensational!!! It's already been demanded of me for Christmas. It was the only dish that had no leftovers. And it was really pretty easy. I followed the recipe to a T except for a few things. I used fresh sage and I think that it wouldn't have been nearly as good if I hadn't. I almost doubled it at others suggestions, 4 tsp. I got fresh turkey stock/broth from the local deli the night before I made it and I think that made it better also. I used 1.5 cups of it since others said to use more if you don't cook it in the turkey. Used the Jimmy Dean Sage sausage as suggested also. Baked at 350 covered for 30 minutes, then uncovered about another 20. Delish!!

text:
Back for a third year to print out the recipe for this awesome stuffing!  You have not eaten stuffing ever before in your life until you try this recipe!  Be sure to use the fresh herbs instead of dried herbs, because that is a big part of what makes the flavor so complex and wonderful.  Everyone who tasted this stuffing at Thanksgiving last year said that it was the best stuffing they had ever tasted, and my sister said that if I didn't bring it for Thanksgiving dinner this time, she would cry (and she's a grown-up!)  You will not regret taking the time to learn this one--it may become a holiday favorite!

text:
Made this for family Thanksgiving.  Loved it!  Would definitely make it again.  I used the sage Jimmy Dean Sausage, soaked Craisins in water and heated in microwave so they would not dry out the stuffing.  Doubled the stock and could have used more.  Used the Golden Delicious and I think I will try Granny Smith apples next time.  Loved it with the fresh herbs as well.  Definitely worth getting the fresh herbs.  I even used the herbs and drippings in the pan from cooking the sausage in my gravy and it added some kick to the gravy that I really liked.

I made this for the first time this year, and used the sage pork sausage as recommended, and other than that, did not deviate from the recipe at all.    It was all right, nobody of the 20 people we had over was particularly impressed with this stuffing.  NO ONE went back for seconds and we had a ton of leftovers, which we unfortunately did not want.    I think everyone missed the bacon/celery/onion stuffing I usually make. I won't be making it again.

text:
WOW, I've never been a stuffing person - till now.  Last night was my first full Thanksgiving dinner where my family and my fiance's met for the first time at our home.  A really big deal so trying this new recipe along with other new dishes was risky.  I used the JD Sage Sausage (and used a bit less sage in case of overload), bagged toasted bread cubes and cornbread stuffing as suggested by others, the liver that came with my turkey, and a carton of chicken stock since I was not stuffing my bird.  Covered for 45 mins at 350 then uncovered for 15.  Was still very watery and had no form so I put it back in multiple times till I reached the desired consistency.    Everyone remarked about how good this tasted.  I only wish I made more.  After leftovers were divided up, I had only a serving left for myself.

text:
This was excellent! I have never made stuffing or dressing before so I was a little aprehensive. However, this was so easy and it was wonderful. I followed the recipe exactly.  My husband and son do not like cranberries and I love them so I scooped about 1/3 into a seperate baking dish, added the cranberries and baked both in baking dishes rather than stuffing the bird.  I had to add more stock to prevent it from drying out in the oven since it was not in the bird.  Baked for about 45 minutes to 1 hour and it smelled and tasted heavenly!  Thank you for posting this recipe.

I used three boxes of Jiffy cornbread baked in an 11x15 pan for my bread base, which worked great.  I sauteed the onions, celery and sausage separately and then sprinkled the herbs on, and mixed in the craisins and apple.  I baked my dressing for an hour at 350 and stirred it a few times throughout baking.  I'd never done a dressing before, and wanted to do something different.  I think everyone was pleasantly surprised and would eat it again.

userID:
664630
Display Name:
Sweets
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for Thanksgiving this year.  I have never made homemade stuffing before, but this turned out FANTASTIC.  I changed the process a little bit.  First, I browned the sausage with a little bit of oil, and chopped onion and garlic.  When the sausage was no longer pink, I added the peeled and chopped apple and the cranberries, and covered it all with a mixture of chicken stock and water (my brother had made the same recipe the day before for his own Thanksgiving dinner, and said that it was very very salty, so I didn't want to use all chicken stock.)  I let everything simmer over medium low heat in the fry pan for about 40 minutes, to really meld the flavors together.  This mixture alone tasted fantastic.  I didn't make my own breadcrumbs, instead using a bag of Pepperidge Farms herbed bread crumbs.  I emptied the bag of bread crumbs into a 9x13" cake pan and poured the sausage mixture over it, then tossed to combine and added some more liquid.  I probably used about 3-4 cups of liquid total in the end.  I covered it with foil and let it sit in the fridge overnight, then popped it in the oven (350 degrees) for 1 1/2 hours the next day.  I probably should have only baked it for an hour, because it got a little over-brown on the bottom and formed kind of a chewy crust, so I think it got overdone.  But it still tasted amazing.  Everyone who tried it loved it.  Will definitely be making this again.
Review:

text:
This was not just awesome stuffing--it was bitchin’! I will use this recipe every Thanksgiving from now on because it’s pretty much fail-proof.  I did change the recipe a bit however. To start with, I used Mrs. Cubbins herb seasoned stuffing mix for convenience, sage sausage for flavor, grated my apple, used craisins for the dried cranberries (they were all I had), fresh herbs and added walnuts for a crunch that would have been lacking. Also I added a carrot, onion, and celery that I sautéed with the sausage. Then mix the thing together adding only enough chicken stock to moisten and covered with foil and baked about 30 mins then removed the foil and let top get crispy. Oh great time of day it was delicious! Thanks for a new favorite Stacy—I love it.

text:
This stuffing was the hit of my Thanksgiving dinner!!!  This is now THE stuffing I will make every year! A number of guests asked for the recipe, and even some diehard stuffing-haters tried and loved this!  I made some of the same changes as other reviewers:  I omitted the turkey liver, I used pre-packaged unseasoned stuffing mix, Jimmy  Dean pork sausage, chicken stock (couldn't find turkey stock anywhere!), and fresh herbs.  I did not stuff my turkey.  I baked the stuffing in a greased casserole dish, approx. 40 min total, covered for the first 30 min, and uncovered for last 10.  I also stirred it halfway through the baking time and drizzled in additional stock to keep it moist, but not mushy.)  Thanks again for a great recipe!

text:
This recipe is FANTASTIC. Instead of toasting my own bread, I buy the wheat/white bread crumb mix (no flavor) and use about 5-6 cups, omit the liver, and don't bake it in the turkey. I also used 1.5 lbs. of reduced fat Jimmy Dean pork sausage because we don't have Turkey Sausage in our grocery store. Cook the sausage with the onions and spices like mentioned, then add to the apple/cranberry/bread mixture and stir. Add the turkey stock and mix until moist. Keep warm in the oven at 150 degrees until ready to eat! Voila! Perfect - thank you for this!

text:
Absolutely amazing! SO glad I finally took the time to make this! I just bought cheap sandwich bread and left it out for a day and it worked out well. Made it easier to cut once it was a little stale. Left out the liver and added an ENTIRE can of stock. That's right, an entire can. When my grandma makes her dressing it almost looks like soup when it goes in the oven and it comes out very very moist. i don't like it quite that moist. Putting in an entire can (cook it uncovered  and stir a few times while it cooks) made the moist level exactly how I like it. Baked it at 350 for about 45 min. DELISH! I'd also go ahead and throw in the entire bag of dried cranberries. they're yum. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Very good recipe - the flavors of sweet and savory seem to marry beautifully in this dish.  Peoples tastes are all different though and most of my family just couldn't adjust to sausaage and apples in their stuffing.  I still use the basics of this recipe but to keep my parents happy I cut the apple, cranberries and sausage amounts in half, added one box of "savory herb" stove top to bring up the bread to meat ratio and double the liquid so I can make this outside the bird in my crockpot.  I loved the recipe "as is" but it's still very tasty modified for family preferences.

text:
Finally! After using this recipe for the past 3 years, I finally found ground turkey sausage. With that said, I subbed the dried herbs with 3X fresh herbs. Also, I dried my own cranberries (1 cup fresh cranberries with a sprinkling of sweetener at 200 degrees for 5 hours). In addition, I used 3/4 cup of "Rich Make-Ahead Turkey Gravy" since that is what I had onhand. With these alterations, my husband finally said the stuffing tasted good but he still prefers bread, butter, and onion stuffing.

text:
Amazingly tasty stuffing.  Made this for my Supper Club and everyone raved on how tasty it was.  All went back for seconds.  Minor adjustments include using only whole wheat bread, fresh herbs, sweet Italian turkey sausage, and additional broth to keep it moist since I did not stuff a turkey. Although other reviewers used prepared bread crumbs, I felt making my own was healthier (no additives, corn syrup, etc) and it didn't take more than 10 min to cut the bread up. I baked it covered for 30 minutes.

2654566
Display Name:
gr8cook4u

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/2221.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks for an super recipe! A great marriage of sweet and savory...the few changes I made were: fresh herbs, I use a stock pot put the neck and giblets. Then I add fresh: rosemary; sage; thyme, and as I'm preparing the onions; celery; garlic, etc. for the stuffing I just throw the stuff others would put in the garbage in my stock pot...(I also add carrots, pretty much everything but the kitchen sink...)when the stuffing is ready to be moistened I pull the broth both from my stock pot and the turkey...if you sample the broth you won't believe how yummy it is...nothing compares to homemade! Keep adding water as it cooks down. After dinner(we dine about 2-3pm, so there's plenty of time, debone the turkey, and add the carcass(keep adding water)...I then simmer all the flavors until the bones are dry...strain everything off except the broth...enjoy it fresh, or freeze it in serving size batches. The next time your sick,( so a small cup of this stuff before going to bed will help knock you out), or you need broth you'll NEVER want to reach for "the off shelf" again!!! 
  Oh, the only thing I omit is the liver, I like it, no one else does...and I mix homemade cornbread with white bread...my mom was southern cook and it my tribute to her...always to bring a touch of her to my table!You don't want to forget the most important ingredient...LOVE!

text:
This was my first ever attempt at stuffing. My bf doesn't like pieces of celery & onions, so I was looking for something I could make that would still have flavor enough to be tasty even though I was leaving those things out.
This recipe was delish!
The rosemary and sage gave it such a yummy flavor. The apple and dried cranberries gave it texture and color and the only changes (other than omitting the veggies) I made were to use fresh herbs (doubled amount) and some extra butter brushed over the top the last 10 minutes of baking. Really good stuff!

text:
Made this for the third Thanksgiving in a row, and I always get complimented on this stuffing and/or asked for the recipe! I bake in a casserole dish at 350 degrees: 45 minutes covered, and about 15-30 minutes uncovered, until enough of the broth is absorbed/cooked. The only other minor changes to the recipe: 1) omit liver (sorry, but ewww), and b) used chopped turkey link sausage (sun-dried tomato this year, which was a BIG hit). Thanks for a wonderful recipe!!

text:
Oh gosh, this just became our family recipe for stuffing. I made it for Thanksgiving this year and there wasn't any left at all.  Good thing I made extra and kept a pan back at home or we'd have had no leftovers!  Everyone there (except my five year old son... go figure) asked for that to become the stuffing we have for Thanksgiving in the future.

I made this per the recipe with the exception that, since we made it in the slow cooker instead of stuffing the turkey, I added more turkey broth.  It was wonderful.

When I was reheating the leftovers I had kept back it was just as good.  I also added some toasted pecans for that portion and it made a good addition to the textures.  

I could barely taste the turkey livers; but when I could it was a very nice addition to the complex flavors of this stuffing.   We will *definitely* make this again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-11-30T10:48:17.633

ILYTAT

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this many times and it's simply the best. Please do yourself a favor and use fresh herbs. I never understood why people would take such a shortcut by using dried herbs in a dish like this. It's what MAKES this dish so fabulous! You can dry the leftover herbs by hanging them upside down in a ziplock (with holes punched in) so as not to waste them.

Ive made this with and without the liver and didnt notice much of a difference. If Im pressed for time, I use a bagged bread cubes.

My husband also likes more bread than meat in this dish so sometimes I use less meat and more bread.

One of the best recipes ever. And it freezes well!

text:
I made this for our Thanksgiving dinner, and I thought it was really good. I used italian sausage, decreased the spices a little, and baked it for 350 about 45 minutes, covered with foil...Since it wasn't going inside the turkey, I added more broth for moistness...about 2 C of broth total, and mixed it with my hands until it got the right consistency. Definitely different than my Gramma's stuffing, so my family was kind of skeptical, but I think they enjoyed it...I know I did!

text:
I've made this stuffing for 6 years straight and it's a hit every time.  I don't always stuff the bird, so I took the suggestion of someone here and put the stuffing in a crockpot, set on low for 3 hours and it turns out awesome & moist.  If you prefer it drier, you could remove it from the CP and bake for 20-30min.  One adjustment I do make is to use 2-4 less ounces of meat than called for, I think it balances the flavor and texture out better.

I've never made stuffing from scratch before, and I'm happy that this came out so well and tasted great!! I used Jimmy Dean Sage sausage that other reviewers suggested, and I used 3 tablespoons dried parsley flakes since I couldn't find them fresh. country:
None
text:
Being only 22, this was my very first year cooking Thanksgiving dinner.  I was nervous but decided to go on a hunt for the best stuffing around.  I've never really been a huge stuffing fan anyway but our guests love it & were counting on me.  I found this recipe the week before Thanksgiving & thought it sounded good.  That, plus the excellent reviews, convinced me to try it.  WOW!!!  Boy am I glad I did!  I have changed my mind about not being a stuffing fan.  This was DELICIOUS!  My entire family raved about it & more of it was eaten than any other side dish.  I pretty much followed the recipe except I left out the celery (since most of us don't like it anyway, used chicken stock vs. turkey stock, bought the seasoned pre-cubed bread crumbs, & used the Jimmy Dean pre-cooked sausage (the kind that you can microwave).  I looked for the uncooked turkey sausage but just couldn't find it! I just threw the pre-cooked sausage in a pan with the onions for some heat & to add flavor then cut it all up.  I am so impressed with this recipe as it was quick, easy, & to die for.  Definitely give it a try!  You will not regret it!

text:
This was very delicious. After reading the reviews before attempting, I doubled the recipe but cut down on the sage pork sausage (half the amount) instead of using turkey sausage -which I couldn't find either. I substituted mixed dried fruit instead of cranberries. IDK I felt it was redundant to use cranberries in the stuffing since I already made Cranberry Sauce Extraordinaire from this website. I also made my stuffing outside of the turkey, so I used a 1 full quart of Pacific brand organic, free range, low sodium chicken broth for a doubled recipe. I used what was on the clearance sale shelf at the bakery (breads that would go stale sooner)- sourdough bread and whole wheat dinner rolls. I cut them into cubes and let them dry out overnight before toasting them. The turkey liver was excluded. I saved the giblets to make delicious Giblet Gravy instead. Overall, very elegant, very rich in flavor; not for simple nor underdeveloped palates. My family devoured it! This is a close favorite next to Cornbread stuffing- but I guess that's the Southern girl in me. Will do again for Christmas!

text:
My husband lamented the lengthy prep of this dish (I tripled the recipe AND used fresh herbs, involving him in three trips to the garden: "more, honey, more than that, please!) but, in the end, he proclaimed unceasingly that THIS must be our new traditional stuffing. So, since I will be making this another year :P, here are my notes: 1)Stick with Golden Delicious, not Granny Smith-- the recipe needs a sweet, not another tart component,  2)When using fresh herbs, triple the amounts when substituting for dried. Save brain cells by tripling the handy-dandy "servings" button to "30", and the herb amounts will be listed for you. (Just don't forget to change it back for your other ingredients!) 3) I halved the butter, and it was perfect. Perhaps using mostly sage pork sausage made it greasier than turkey sausage would have. 4)LEFTOVERS IDEA!!! This would make an excellent accompaniment to pork. I plan to place chops, swiss cheese and the leftover stuffing into the slow cooker for our guests tomorrow.

I made this stuffing for the first time this evening for our Thanksgiving dinner.  My whole family loved it.  My mom, who insisted on making her own "traditional" stuffing, tried some of this and thought it was great, to her surprise.  I baked this in a separate pan instead of stuffing it in the turkey.  I doubled the amount of stock/broth, used fresh herbs, used one bag of sage flavored stuffing instead of fresh white bread, used sausage with sage, then baked it covered with foil for 45 minutes and uncovered for 15 minutes at 350 degrees.  I highly recommend this dish!

text:
I have been making this recipe for the past 4 years and it's always a hit! It's amazingly flavorful. I don't use the liver or the celery, instead I use pork sausage. I also add minced bacon (that I pre-cook separately) so it's tastier. Also, like other reviewers suggested, I check it periodically and add stock so it won't be too dry. The first time I cooked this I stuffed half in the bird and cooked the rest on a separate pan. It turns out much much better when you cook it separately! You can't go wrong with this recipe!!

text:
I've been making this for several years now and it always receives rave reviews.  I've substituted chicken broth and the recipe still works just fine.  Sometimes, bulk turkey sausage is hard to find, so I've resorted to using turkey sausage links and removing them from the casings.  I've also used real cranberries and added honey for sweetness, but I prefer the craisins as the real cranberries tend to be a little bitter.  Personally, I prefer Cortland apples in this recipe as those are my favorite to eat.  Although I'm not a big liver eater, I don't mind it in this recipe.

text:
This was my first attempt at stuffing and boy was it delicious!  It's already been requested for Christmas!  I doubled the recipe for a 22 lb. turked and used an entire loaf of potato bread and about 3/4 loaf of wheat.  I omitted the liver; used fresh herbs where possible; used Jimmy Dean original and sage sausage; used fresh turkey stock and canned chicken stock.  I made it the night before, which I think made it taste that much better.  I added a small can of chicken broth before I stuffed the turkey.  I had enough to bake a large tray as well.  I was actually sad yesterday when I finished the last bit of leftovers!  Thanks for posting this outstanding recipe!

I just made this stuffing past Thanksgiving (Canada) and it turned out pretty good. It was my first time roasting turkey and making stuffing from scratch but it was delicious and my family liked it. text:
I made this stuffing for my husband's and my first Thanksgiving dinner togather.  I chose it because of all the great reviews.  It was awesome!  I almost had to stop myself from nibbling away at it while the turkey was roasting.  I think I made too much for a 10 pound turkey (although the cavity was rather small).  I cooked the leftover on the stovetop.  I modified it a bit, since we don't like cranberries very much, I substituted the cranberries with 1 peeled and cubed pear and I also added a little sliced fried bacon for flavor.  Went very well with the apple.  I will definitley be sticking to this stuffing!  I also served the meal with a Gewurztraminer ... the fruity flavor of the wine complemented everything wonderfully!

text:
I had heard great things about a cranberry, apple and sausage stuffing that a local upscale dining restaurant served during it's Thanksgiving buffet, so I decided to surf the net and see if I could find a recipe for it to make at home.  I was a little skeptical when I saw the ingredients so I stuffed the turkey with this dressing and made an additional pan of regular cornbread dressing.  My husband and family LOVED this dressing.  My reg cornbread dressing is still sitting here in the refrigerator 4 days after thanksgiving but the sausage-cranberry-apple recipe was GONE by the next day.  My husband insisted this dressing replace my usual from here on out!  I used 2x the amount of cranberried and used low fat pork sausage instead of turkey and it turned out excellent.  Thanks for a GREAT recipe!

WOW!!!!!!!!! I took the stuffing to a party last night. BIG HIT!!! I did a few things different. I used the peteridge farm herb seasoning, I used mild italian sausage (because I had some already cooked), and I used chicken stock (about 1 1/2 cans). The apple in it were AWESOME!!!! Thanks so much for posting.

My husband who doesn't usually comment about food unless prompted said spontaneously as he was dishing out leftovers to heat in the microwave, "this is GOOD stuffing." text:
This was certainly a big hit for our Thanksgiving dinner this year.  I doubled the bread portion and most of the other ingredients but not the sausage. I made the stuffing the day before and therefore did not have the turkey stock at that time, so I used canned chicken broth.   I opted not to stuff the turkey like I normally have done for years because of all the caution on the TV shows... So I put it in a casserole and covered it with foil and baked it for about 40 minutes.  

I will make this again.  I might try using a mild Italian sausage next time.   Dried cherries might be a nice change too.  

Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I LOVE this stuffing!  It has all of the flavors of fall ;  apples, onions,  sausage.  Not too sweet, which is important to me and when I use fresh herbs instead of the dried, the flavors come even more alive, if that's even possible.
I used regular pork sausage because it's what I already had in the freezer, and I left out the liver because it doesn't appeal to my family.  Everything else just came together beautifully.
I HIGHLY recommend this stuffing recipe!  Oh!  I almost forgot...  I toasted some walnuts and rough chopped them to add to the dish...   I AM THANKFUL!  :-D

userID:

Display Name:
kmoku146

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this recipe! I found it years ago and have been making it ever since for every Thanksgiving. I hate going to others' houses for Thanksgiving because I know they'll use some cheap, $0.99 box of stuffing... No thank you! I did end up changing this recipe a little bit. I don't go very heavy on the seasonings because they end up being a little too strong for my taste (basically, the teaspoons aren't level... just barely under the line). I usually use whatever apple I have on hand and definitely lay off the parsley (again, too strong for my taste). Instead of turkey sausage, I use regular ground sausage (maple flavored) because who's trying to be healthy for THANKSGIVING?! Also, I don't even add the turkey liver or turkey stock. I just leave that out completely. We do a maple-brined turkey which is seriously the best thing you could ever do to a turkey so the maple sausage and the sweetness of this stuffing blends so well together. Finally, I usually split the stuffing into 2 different bowls right before I stuff the turkey. Again, this is just for preference because my husband likes the stuffing straight out of the turkey but I think it's gross when the bread/croutons are soggy and wet so now everyone is happy... and hungry. I'm hungry just writing this review for this amazing stuffing!!

city:

country:
None
text:
This was really tasty and everyone enjoyed the recipes. I made a few modifications for time and taste:
I used sage turkey sausage (no casing) from Whole Foods. The recipe also calls for turkey liver; they are small and you hardly notice the texture so next time I might use two.
I used cornbread and unseasoned white bread crumbs (pre-packaged Petridge Farms for time).
I also used chicken stock. It calls for 3/4 cups and I thought this was really dry. Luckily I prepared at least 4 cups, adding to the mix to reach the consistency I prefered.
I added fresh ground black pepper and sea salt and almost doubled the sage.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My to stuffing recipe to bake outside the bird. Since I prefer my stuffing baked outside the bird and this one is meant to go "inside the bird", I increase broth to 3 to 3-1/2 cups and toss in 2-3 raw eggs to keep it moist & help bind it together. I swapped out the turkey liver for 1 smoked or baked chicken thigh diced up. Bake the stuffing mixture @ 350 degrees in a large baking dish for 30 minutes covered with foil then remove foil & cook for another 15 min. making top crispy & the bottom moist & de-lish!

I highly recommend this, even for the beginning cook.

I grew up on cornbread dressing, but wanted to try something new several years back. This stuff is like crack! It gets eaten up very quickly because most people go back for seconds or thirds. text:
I have been making a very similar apple, sausage stuffing since my first Thanksgiving dinner. Hubby and the kids do not like cranberry so I just use the apple and sausage. My version uses a total of 1 cup liquid in the form of 1/2 cup chicken stock and 1/2 cup apple juice or cider. Makes it a little moister and more flavorful also. For the sausage I like the JD maple flavored links for even more flavor. The stuffing is always the best part of the meal and people beg me to make it every year.

country:
None
text:
Yummy recipe!   I love the sweet/savory idea of dried cranberries with sausage.  All I had onhand was Italian sausage, and unfortunately that did not work at all with the flavor profile of the stuffing... oops!   I used fresh herbs (twice as much as dried) and I felt the combo was too heavy on the sage and rosemary, and too light on the thyme.  In general I think rosemary and sage go great with sausage, but thyme goes better with poultry, so consider what this stuffing will be served with and adjust accordingly.

text:
this is a FANTASTIC recipe! i was nervous about trying it out, but it turned out great! i'm really glad i decided to go for it. i did, however, use jimmy dean sage sausage instead of the turkey sausage since i couldn't find any. i made it as directed and it tasted wonderful, but it didn't have clumpyness that i'm used to in a stuffing, so i put everything in a 9x13 pan and drizzled a little more stock to it and put it in the oven at 350 for about 15 minutes.  came out delicious! will definitely be using this for christmas!

My family was so skeptical about this recipe but ended up loving it!  We don't put it in the bird so as other reviews have stated make sure to have extra stock so it's not too dry.   When in a pinch for time you can use pre-dried bread cubes from the grocery store. Literally reduced the cook time down to preparing ingredients and heating the stock!  Enjoy.

text:
I made this stuffing for Thanksgiving 2 days ago and it was AWESOME.  I will never use another recipe again.  My whole family loved it.  Even though they were making fun of me as I was making it.   I read a lot of reviews saying that people didn't stuff it into their turkey, but I REALLY recommend it!  I had a small turkey, and stuffed it as full as I could and had plenty left over to put in a casserole dish.  After they both came out, everyone in the family thought that the stuffing in the bird was better then the stuffing in the dish.   Both were delicious, but the turkey gives the stuffing so much extra flavor!!  Great recipe!  Thanks Stacy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this stuffing for the first time this Thanksgiving. My husband, who doesn't eat stuffing, couldn't get enough of it.  I used a bag of pepperigde farm dried bread seasoned stuffing mix, cut the amount of herbs in half (since the mix was already seasoned), cooked the onion with the sausage, and omitted the turkey liver. Since, I cooked the stuffing separate from the bird, I used a whole carton of chicken stock to keep the stuffing moist. I baked it in a 13 x 9 pyrex dish for about 30 or 40 minutes covered with foil. I took the foil off for the last 10 minutes to get a little crispiness. This will be my turkey stuffing for years to come!

This was awesome, with the tweaks I made. No turkey liver or parsley (don't care for either), doubled and used fresh herbs (to die for), used Sage Pork Sausage, used good sourdough bread in place of white bread and potato bread in place of whole wheat. I made this recipe for Thanksgiving, and it was absolutely delicious. I followed the recipe, except that I cooked it in a casserole dish in the oven, instead of inside the bird. I used 1 1/2 cups of stock instead of 3/4, on the advice of some other reviewers here. The flavor was sensational! It was moist, rich and delicious. This recipe is too good to save for Thanksgiving -- I'm sure I'll be making this dish often.

text:
I love this stuffing! It is fabulous. I will share this recipe with everyone I know. My boyfriend also loved it and he usually smothers his stuffing in gravy just to be able to eat it. He said its the best he has ever had, (with no gravy)! The only change I made was to use quite a bit more liquid as I like my stuffing very moist and I did not use bullion, instead i simmered some of the herbs from the recipe in chicken broth and used a 1/2 cup of that along with broth from my turkey. It was wonderful!

text:
Wow! I hate stuffing but my aunt asked me to make it for thanksgiving because I'm known for bringing new and creative recipes to family events. This was outstanding...I could eat it straight for dinner! I made several changes based on personal preferences...I used bagged corn bread stuffing cubes and white bread cubes (faster and easier...we are a corn bread type of family), I used turkey keilbasa instead of sausage (not big on sausage), and I opted not to add the liver (just not my thing). This wasn't dry at all as long as you added a little extra broth and checked it every 15 minutes (adding more as needed). I baked it at 350 for 30 minutes covered and 15 uncovered. Highly recommend this recipes!!!!

userID:
3422695
Display Name:
FoodKrazed

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What an awesome stuffing! For this recipe, I also left it out of the bird. I like my stuffing moist, but not drenched. I used Farmer John's Old Fashioned Maple Sausage, or traditional  non-cooked sausage, and the smell just made my mouth water. It is a bit more fatty, but it's once a year.. so why not?! I didn't have sage herbs so I didn't put any and it tasted just fine without it. I used Craisins because I don't like tart and Fuji apple which tasted great. For the bread I used 5 cups of both sweet bread and sourdough. The stuffing turned a little more on the sweeter side, but my guests raved about it all night as they scraped for pieces. This style doesn't have too much bread, so it's really meaty.  Try doubling the bread or decreasing to only 1/2 lb of sausage. If using more bread add 2 to 3 tbs butter.(Using only 1 can) I also used chicken broth every 20 min without drowning. Stirred as one of the reviews stated. Cooked another 30 min, added more. And another thirty. Stirring gently does help cook evenly. Add the broth or stock gradually to the consistency you prefer. A friend even said he could just eat the whole tray by itself! I knew I should have double the batch. Great recipe!
Review:

I used all white bread cubes for this recipes, used pork instead of turkey sausage, chicken instead of turkey stock and left out the liver. Will definately use it again.

text:
My family was nervous about how this might turn out, but were all singing my praises once I was through with them! I made a happy mistake of picking up cilantro instead of parsley and they demanded I keep it in the recipe because it added to the flavor well. Feel free to add extra apples! Oh, and it's especially wonderful with a cranberry-orange relish my grandmother made.

Display Name:
Mrs. Kingry

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2827108.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This year was my first time ever making Thanksgiving and I decided at the last minute to make my stuffing from scratch AND stuff the Turkey.  I am SO glad I did as this stuffing was my favorite part of the entire meal!  I had a 10-pound turkey and I was concerned that this recipe wouldn't make enough stuffing for the meal plus leftovers, so I doubled it...and ended up with twice as much stuffing as I needed!  Also, one batch went into the turkey and one batch was baked separately and I will say that the in-turkey stuffing was much tastier and moister than the other pan.  Also, in one batch I used homemade whole-cranberry sauce and Craisins in the other, and I preferred the sauce version.  The cranberries blended more with the other ingredients in every bite, rather than remaining slightly hard/chewy and standing out.  I also threw in a bunch of chopped walnuts that I thought turned out to be a key ingredient. I used bagged cubed Pepperidge Farm stuffing, sage sausage, left out the liver and rosemary (forget to buy it...) and doubled the fresh herbs.  This could not have been more delicious and it will be a staple for me from here on out!

1
userID:
2525309
Display Name:
Janice
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:
7
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is so yummy.  I've taken the advice of other reviewers and used Jimmy Dean Sage Sausage.  I always use fresh herbs for holiday cooking.  The addition of fresh sage with the sage sausage was a little much though.  Next time I'll do one or the other.  I staled my own sourdough bread cubes, and I have to say I prefer french bread for this stuffing as there are already so many strong flavors in it.  I left out the liver because I don't like it, and even though I only put in a little bit of the rosemary, I'll leave it out next year.  I just don't like it.  I used a Honey Crisp apple because it would not get mushy.  I didn't stuff the bird and so used a lot more broth than the recipe calls for.  Also, next year I will try to add an egg to help with binding.  The only real mistake I made this year was I followed the advice of another reviewer and put everything together except for the broth the day before and then added the butter and broth just before cooking.  My bread cubes got soft just sitting in the fridge with the other ingredients.  If you need to make this ahead of time, I recommend keeping the sausage mixture separate from the bread until you are ready to either stuff the bird or bake it in the oven.  Great recipe and easy to alter to make it your own.

text:
Incredible stuffing recipe – was the hit of our Thanksgiving table!  I did not stuff the bird but baked the stuffing in a 9 x 13 casserole, covered for about 40 minutes.  I used Jimmy Dean Sage Prok Sausage, added extra stock to moisten and used all fresh herbs- I did not use turkey liver and it was still AMAZING. I will NEVER use another stuffing recipe for Thanksgiving- This dish will be a staple at holiday dinners for years to come!

text:
Phenomenal!!  This was the first time we made this recipe and it will definitely become a staple at our holiday dinners.  Because we couldn't find turkey sausage, we used fresh pork sausages (casings removed). Delish!  We used 2 kinds whole wheat bread from the bakery.  Omitted the turkey liver because we didn't have one from the turkey this year.  The only other change made was increasing the chicken stock to about 2 cups.  Didn't measure exactly - just added stock until the mixture looked moist enough to go in the oven for 40 minutes.  The only problem is we don't have any leftovers!

I used this recipe yesterday- it's the first time I have ever made stuffing - it turned out perfectly! Since we were smoking our bird I wasn't able to stuff it, so I made the stuffing early in the day and put it in the crockpot instead. It worked wonderfully! I just stirred it every couple of hours so it wouldn't get too crispy against the sides of the pot, and it worked great! Everyone loved it. I left our the liver and used the sage Jimmy Dean sausage as someone else suggested. Great recipe!

text:
Made it yesterday for Thanksgiving and EVERYONE LOVED IT! I used Jimmy Dean Sage Pork Sausage, Pepperidge Farm cornbread stuffing and unseasoned cubed stuffing from a bag. I left out the liver and celery, personal preference. I made it the night before and then put it in my slow cooker on high for 2 hours to warm and added some turkey broth to prevent it from drying. I will definately make this again. Everyone is already requesting it for Xmas. I doubled the recipe for 14 people and only had a little bit left.

When I made this recipe, i made a few changes. I used pork italian sausage, and i felt that it was just a little dry, so insted of using dry cranberries, i put fresh cranberries in 1/3 cup of sugar and 1/3 cup of water and boiled it for ten minutes to make a sauce, and put that in insted. Everybody in my family ate it up like animals!

text:
This is THE best stuffing ever!  I used it last year, and my husband raved for hours and even told his friends about how it good it was.  He won't let me make any other kind now!  I used golden delicious apples, but think that granny smith apples would be equally delicious.  I used dried cranberries, and the tartness of the cranberries mixed with the sweetness of the apples, added in with the yummy turkey sausage (I used breakfast turkey sausage in the 1 lb tube, you can find it in the ground turkey section) is heavenly!  I do stuff my turkeys, and it turned out incredibly moist.  Just be warned, once you make this you will be responsible for all of the Thanksgiving dinners from here on out!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice now and love it everytime.  The second time, I didn't add enough chicken broth (Cooked outside of the turkey) and the bread was a bit dry.  I made this the day before.  Used Granny smith apple, and Jimmy dean Sage sausage as suggested.  I also used fresh herbs the second time around and it was more flavorful than the first time when I used dried.  I used potato and sourdough bread the first time which was perfect.  I used french bread and potato the second time and prefer the sourdough over the french.  I drizzled it with butter before refridgerating and then let the mixture come to room temperature before baking for 30 minutes the next day.  1/2-3/4 of the can of chicken broth would get it moist enough for me next time, but that is personal preference.

country:
None
text:
My family raved over this recipe.  I can't stress enough how important it is to use fresh herbs.  The aroma and taste were both to die for.  I highly recommend chopping all of your vegetables and herbs the night before and setting them aside, as this will save value time the morning of Thanksgiving/Christmas.  It will take longer than you think, but it's worth it.  As for the bread, I used sourdough and wheat, but next time I think I'll use potato bread.  I think sourdough may not have been the best choice though is was good and recommended by other reviewers. I used pork sausage with sage which was FABULOUS.  I also added a handful of pecans... yummy.  This makes a ton of stuffing, so if you're having less than about 10 people, I would scale it back.  I will use this recipe every year.

Great recipe! We will make this a staple at our Thanksgiving table! Very easy and turned out great, I cut the bread in cubes the night b4 and left it out overnight to get crunchy I didn't toast the cubes in the oven. I used the turkey broth from boiling the giblets but was planning on using chicken broth. I kept adding more bread cubes once I started mixing the broth in and realized the recipe called for stuffing the turkey.. OOPS! Turkey was already in the oven, cooked stuffing in a casserole dish for 30 minutes on 375. You can mess with this recipe all day and it will still come out fantastic!

text:
This is an awesome recipe. This is the firs time I've made stuffing from scratch, and was very pleased with the results. I did make a few changes, though.

I left out the liver, and used Bob Evan's savory sage sausage instead of turkey sausage.

I added the sausage mixture, apple, and cranberries, to 5 cups of toasted sourdough bread cubes, and poured the butter and 1 cup of chicken broth over it.

Instead of cooking it inside the turkey, I baked it in the oven, covered, at 350 for an hour. It turned out moist and perfect.

I made this outside the bird and had to use a lot of extra broth to keep it moist.  Also added two beaten eggs to bind it all together.  It was a bit sweet for me (maybe from the craisins I used?) and didn't get all that great reviews from my family.  I also didn't like the "crunch" of the bits of apple.  Will stick with the regular bread stuffing from now on.  Also took a lot more time than it stated in the directions.

It seems silly for me to leave a review since there are well over 600 positive reviews already, but I just have to add my thoughts. My husband and I got married three months ago and thought it would be nice to stay in town and celebrate Thanksgiving together in our new home. It was the first Thanksgiving meal I'd prepared and the first time I'd made stuffing from scratch: what a confidence booster! This was great and my husband was so impressed as well. Next year, we'll be traveling to go to my Grandma's like I have since childhood, but I'm going to offer to bring the stuffing! Thank you!

text:
I would've given this 4.5 stars instead..  I, personally, thought this was delicious! My family enjoyed it too, but no one raved about it except myself.. So because of that I had to give it 4 stars..

Also, other reviewers had suggested to add more stock if you want it mushier since it's not the typical thanksgiving mush... but no one stated how much more.  Well, the recipe calls for 3/4 cups.  I put in 1.5 cups and it came out nice and moist but it wouldn't hurt to just put in the entire 16oz can (2 cups).  I think i'm going to do that next time. 

I don't care if it didn't get raves, i'm still making this next year! I def. prefer this fresher version of stuffing to stovetop.

text:
I made this for Canadian Thanksgiving this weekend and it turned out great.  I had bought all the ingredients listed and at the last minute found out that one of my guests was a vegetarian.  I omitted the meat in this recipe and was worried about still being able to achieve good flavour, so I increased the amount of broth (I used vegetable stock), herbs, cranberries and apple.  I also added a veggie cube in with the onion and celery as I was sauteeing in butter.  Awesome results!!  I followed some other reviewers suggestions and used sourdough and rosemary potato bread.  Delicious!  Very happy with this recipe and will definitely make it again and again, with or without meat.

Display Name:
Alejandra Gonzalez

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2738064.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe  for about 8 years now and it has become a Thanksgiving tradition! If you're not the biggest fan of stuffing, this stuffing might change your mind! The first time I read the recipe I misread it and purchased just regular pork/beef sausage because I couldn't find "turkey sausage". Years later I realized that it said "ground turkey sausage". Oops! The thing is that it tastes great with regular sausage. I cut it up in little squares and it tastes DELICIOUS! Finally last year I tried doing it the right way but I am going back to the sausage. Much more flavorful.  I also used sourdough bread last year like one user recommended and it did taste much better. I have used both dry and fresh herbs. Fresh is definitely better and don't forget to double up if using fresh herbs. I do it on the stove top because I don't like stuffing my turkey so I use double the broth, at least. I stop when I think I'm happy with the texture. I'm not a fan of extremely mushy stuffing so use a lot of broth if that's how you like yours. Anyway... do this recipe!! It's da' bomb and this is coming from someone that did not like stuffing for years. :)

text:
I was excited to try this recipe for Thanksgiving, and I had read most other reviews.  Since so many people had said that this recipe can turn out dry, I added about a half cup more stock.  I cooked my turkey in a bag and stuffed it, and I had some extra that didn't fit, so I cooked it in the bag next to the turkey.  The juices from the turkey made ths stuffing a little soggy.  It still tasted great, but if you cook your turkey in a bag, keep in mind that the stuffing will absorb some of the juice.  Great recipe- a nice change from stovetop!

text:
My whole family loved this recipie, even though I made it vegetarian.  Substituted soy sausage for turkey sausage and vegetable broth for turkey stock; omitted turkey liver; increased amount of broth, onion, celery, apple; used fresh herbs.  Prepare for a serious time investment, especially if you add extra liquid.  After baking in dishes, it came out slightly crispy on the top and chewy/moist/soft inside.  I made a double batch for 6 people, and NONE was left over.  Delicious!

text:
I have to say, this stuffing was incredible!And I have very high standards for food. I made this for Thanksgiving 04 and it was a big hit! Was my 1st time making stuffing, and I am SOOOO glad I didn't use some mushy Stovetop recipe. I left out the liver and parsley, and doubled the dried cranberries, also I added about 1/2 cup extra stock since I baked it in a dish instead of stuffing in into a turkey. And I used canned chicken broth instead of turkey stock. After I browned the sausage with the onion I pureed them in a food processor to make a smoother texture. Will be making this for Christmas!

I made this for the first time three years ago when I stumbled upon it while looking for a decent stuffing recipe, followed the recipe to a T. Everyone enjoyed it but I felt like there was just a little too much meat, so the next year I halved the sausages and it was perfect!

I didn't make it last year and I regret it, but I've made it this year and instead of Turkey sausage I have used honey garlic sausage from Costco and its absolutely divine! A huge hit in this house. Will definitely continue to make it this way!

text:
My sister found this recipe about 10 years ago, and since then it has been our “family recipe”. I have even integrated it into my in laws side where they request it every holiday! Only changes I make - I omit the turkey liver, use chicken stock, and use mild Italian pork sausage. This recipe is very forgiving when it comes to less/more ingredients depending on palate. I start with the recommended amount of spice although sometimes have thrown in a bit extra. Hands down only stuffing recipe I’ll ever use again! Always a hit first time round.

text:
A.w.e.s.o.m.e! I stuffed a brined bird. Used fresh rosemary and thyme. Replaced sausage with chicken liver and added sage, allspice, pimento peppers, cranberries infused with strawberry juice and honey roasted pecans. Used cranberry walnut sourdough bread. Massaged the bird with salt, black pepper, cinnamon, allspice, grated garlic, sage, bay leaves, lime wedges and butter. Put Idaho potato wedges around to soak up the juices. And voila! Yum yum stuffing plus juicy turkey and baked potato wedges equals empty pan! No leftovers!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The stuffing was a huge hit. I cooked it outside the bird. I made it with Gluten free bread. I bought a loaf of gluten free white and a loaf of gluten free ancient wheat to cut up and toast. I kept a close eye on them bcz over-toasting them isnt a great idea. I also used dried cranberries which added extra sweetness and a nice texture element. I tripled the recipe, used an entire box of turkey stock bcz it seemed REALLY dry without it.  Our gluten intolerant guests were more than thrilled at Thanksgiving that they finally got to have stuffing again! I made enough for everyone and had 3 boxes of cardboard instant stuffing just in case it didnt turn out. One thing I wish I had done was to make this a day in advance. The flavors when combined overnight are so delicious and satisfying. TRY IT!

text:
HUGE HIT!  I used pork sausage and doubled the recipe and it was fantastic. Like others, I cooked it outside the bird -- two 9×13 casserole dishes at 350 for 50 min covered with foil, then added more broth and cooked uncovered for 10. Omitted the liver. Used equal mix of white, wheat and sourdough. Added two eggs, but next time I'll add three. Used fresh thyme and rosemary (3/4 T each). Added salt, pepper and garlic powder. 

MY NEW GO-TO STUFFING!!

Display Name:
SamySeal

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe for the last 7 years and  it never fails me. Tonight we'll have 35 for Thanksgiving dinner. I've made it for as few as 11 and up to 35, the recipe scales very well. We never stuff the bird, but bake in the oven. I do as other reviewers suggest and add extra stock as needed during baking. Also as another reviewer suggests, give it a stir after 30 minutes to help baking it evenly and not drying the edges out. I get compliments on this each time I make this recipe. It's a good one! For the vegans and vegetarians in the family this can be made using a vegetable stock and omitting the sausage.  Fresh herbs are the key, just know that that you will have to convert the amount of fresh vs dried herbs--it's not 1 to 1 ration for sure!

Roya Greco

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7339111.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the ONLY stuffing recipe you will need to know for years to come... so delicious you'll wish you could have it all year round. I've personally been making this one for years, and it really is the best. 

As other people have said, fresh herbs will make a huge difference, so do that & double the amount. I also always end up using fresh cranberries instead of the dried ones since I already have them in the kitchen for cranberry sauce. Before adding them to the bread cube mixture, I put them in a pan with some butter over medium heat for 4-5 minutes just long enough to get them blistered.  That helps them cook better in the oven and really release the flavors. Some people have said they don't stuff the bird with this but bake it in a separate dish - I do both. I've stuffed all kinds of birds with this stuffing - Cornish game hens, whole chickens, and of course turkey for Thanksgiving. I'll put the rest in a dish and cook on the side (add more broth and cover with foil).

text:
A lot of other reviewers made this recipe as written and loved it, but I had some issues and I noticed that other reviewers loved it but made significant changes in how they made it. I used ground turkey that I seasoned myself the day before making this dish but I know know that I if I make it again I will use a pork sage sausage. It just has a different mouth feel along with the obvious flavor and fat content differences.  I used the directions others gave for using a 13x9 pan and it baked up ok. Like others, I used more bread than the recipe called for, and therefore more broth, more apple, more rehydrated cranberries since I had more space than a turkey carcass to work with. It was just ok if not a little disappointing. I think more butter in the broth might have helped my expanded version because of my low fat turkey. I still gave it 4 stars because of the many changes I made and the variables of my ‘turkey sausage’. I just wanted to point out that others made a lot of changes and still gave it 5 stars , so buyer beware.

country:

text:
This is the best stuffing I've ever had and I'm a stuffing/dressing junkie.  It's my favorite side during the holidays.  I'm a good cook and great at improvising, but I've never liked any complex or extremely unique variations people have made (oysters and nuts in stuffing?  Not going on my plate).  My mom made good stuffing when I was young but nothing that beat the flavor of Stove Top and usually it was mushy.

I've never heard anyone at any holiday dinner compliment anyone about stuffing before, until tonight when I made this.  Almost every person said it was spectacular.  Every year there is usually a lot of stuffing left and this year everyone had seconds of stuffing and there was about 1 cup left that I ate later...that's never happened around here!  I did make some adjustments and prepared it different than the recipe after watching a chef make a similar recipe.

I used about 3/4 loaf of the Old Fashioned Potato Bread (wider slices) and about 3 slices of Safeway Signature whole wheat bread (the wider slices also).  I used mild italian chicken sausage and increased all the ingredients since I was using slightly more bread.  The night before dinner I cut the bread into about 3/4in-1in cubes and dried it in the oven at 200F for about 40 minutes on a cookie sheet, flipping the cubes about every 5-8 minutes until they were dry like croutons.

I didn't like the idea of dumping the liquid over the bread because I wanted all ingredients blended well, so I did it the way I saw

text:
This was so amazing!  I've never been a stuffing person, but I could eat this all day, every day.  I doubled the recipe for Thanksgiving dinner and made a few other changes.  I used the sage sausage that had been talked about often in the comments.  I used all sourdough and added several cups.  I skipped the turkey liver because I didn't have one and used chicken stock because I couldn't find turkey.  I prepped everything the day before, but waited to add the bread and stock.  I didn't stuff a bird with it, but rather, cooked in a crock pot.  Because of that and because the family likes more of a mushy stuffing, I added A LOT of stock.  I think  I used a full box.  I also used fresh herbs (except for the rosemary because I forgot it at the store) and used less sage because the sausage already had it.  I know I made a ton of modifications, but this recipe is an incredible base to play with.  I'll probably be volunteering to make this every year because it got rave reviews across the board.

None
text:
Been making this recipe for years now, just never rated. I love love love this recipe. A few tips: the JD sage flavored sausage is wonderful. Use fresh herbs if you can, especially Parsley and Rosemary. Next time, I will increase the bread as the ratio seems low next to the other ingredients. When cutting bread to make the croutons, if you cut about 6 cups of fresh bread it will reduce down to about 5 cups once dried, so be sure to adjust for this. I baked it in a pan and then transferred to a slow cooker to keep it warm at the family gathering as I wasn't confident that it would have a crispy top if I cooked entirely in the slow cooker. Truly one of my favorite recipes on this site! Thank you Stacy!

0
madeRecipesCount:
29
favoritesCount:
128
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5397765.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow. This is the second time I've made this for Thanksgiving and it is just so good. This time, I tried crumbling corn bread and it wasn't as good as the original, so I'll go back to that. Also, I used both fresh and dried herbs and seasoned the pork sausage with a bit of sage, rosemary, thyme, parsley, pepper, some garlic salt, and Italian seasoning in addition to the spices in the recipe - as I had unseasoned sausage and other reviewers had recommended sage pork sausage. As other reviewers suggested, I increased the liquid since I didn't cook it in the turkey. I used 1/2 cup butter and 2.5 cups chicken stock. Stirring it halfway through really helped make sure that all the bread was moist and that it cooked evenly. Next time, I will also add an egg to help it bind together more.

text:
Our go to dressing, we’ve made it for the past 10 Thanksgivings and it’s always a favorite. Don’t stuff your turkey!!! It drys it out and is potentially unsafe.
Butter a baking dish and cook for 40min covered at 375 and 20-30 min uncovered to make the top nice and crunchy.
Use homemade turkey for that yummy turkey flavor.

text:
What a great recipe!  The best part was that I could do most of it the night before so there was less to do on thanksgiving day.  I just reserved all of the butter and stock until I was ready to put it into the oven and it worked perfectly, total hit!  I did make 2 substitutions - I couldn't find turkey stock so I used chicken stock (and bumped it up to 1 cup since I like moist stuffing), and I used pork sausage instead of turkey sausage (but drained it before adding it to the bread mixture).  Will for sure make again!

text:
This was a hit.  Only thing I did differently  was along with the celery, onion, and spices, I also threw in The cranberries and sautéed them along with the veggies and once done transferred the mixture to the bread cubes  and added an egg to make it sticky. Transferred to a loaf pan as opposed to just a cookie sheet. The loaf came out great and much easier to cut and eat and less mess overall.

text:
This recipe was a huge hit at Thanksgiving! I used fresh herbs in place of dried. I doubled the amount of fresh herbs. I also did not stuff the bird with the stuffing so I used 2 cups of stock. I placed it in a 9x13 dish and covered it with foil. I cooked it for 40 minutes at 350 degrees stirring half way through. Then I removed the foil and cooked for an additional 20 minutes.  This is our new go to stuffing recipe.

region:

country:
None
text:
Have made this recipe for 3-5 yrs and even my non-fancy husband Loves it in the detriment of his mama's cornbread stuffing. I use spicy italian sausage always, low sage and thyme and fresh rosemary. It stays outside the turkey. A key step is to dry the bread the day/week before. Don't use fresh bread and always use german or home made bread (i make my own in bteadmaker and always use leftover stale bread for drying). I bake for 45 min or 1 hr uncovered and cover if it gets too brown. We love it! Freezes well!

Following the other reviews, because I was not stuffing a turkey, I mixed 1 egg and 1 cup chicken stock, drizzled over, tossed it, baked 300* for about 30 minutes, tossed it again, baked another 10 minutes.

text:
This recipe was delicious! I used one bag of unseasoned pepperidge farm stuffing and one pound hot sausage. I cooked it in a cassserole dish, so it did need a lot more liquid. I used 3 cups chicken stock and one 14 oz can chicken broth. As the other reviews suggested, I baked it at 350 degrees. 20 minutes cover and then 20 minutes uncovered. Toss it a little after removing from the oven and voila- beautiful, super tasty stuffing. Thank you so much for this recipe!

This stuffing recipe is AMAZING. I double herbs because I use fresh.  I also used, and highly recommend mild Italian sausage instead of turkey for that added flavour.  I cooked it in the slow cooker for 2.5 hours and required 3 cups chicken stock.  I don't have a medium setting so cooked on high first half then low the rest. This is going to be my go-to stuffing from now on.
***added note-I"ve made this many times now and it's always a hit.  I've also cooked this in a casserole dish at 350, covered with foil for 40 mins then uncovered for 15 mins.

text:
I make this every thanksgiving and christmas for my family and friends. We deep fry our turkey in the driveway so I make this is a big casserole dish in the oven and it's very good. I don't even eat stuffing (until now). You can add more or less stock to make it softer or crunchier depending on your preference.  I've made it both ways and it's all a matter of preference. Make it once with cooked chopped bacon in it too, delish!
I omit the liver, cuz,, why bother. and I have made it with and without the craisins. and any kind of apple will do, but the crisper the better, no soft apples.
