text:
I've made this for several years now. One year I thought I would try a different recipe and the family wasn't happy so I've gone back to this one. Definitely a keeper! It's a lot of sausage in this recipe so make sure you use a sausage that you like. It is a very hearty recipe so if you want less sausage, more bread then feel free to do so, it would still be delicious. Also as in any recipe that uses bread, using a good, or preferably home-made bread makes it so much better! Yum!

Edited to add that I've used both liver and no liver. The family didn't notice either way so I tend to skip it now. ;)

text:
I've been making this for years now!  I don't use it to stuff turkey, just put it in a separate casserole dish.  Extra stock  is needed to make it more moist when it's not stuffed in the turkey.  I use sage sausage only for meat, and 1/2 what's called for (original recipe just has too much meat and not enough bread).  ALWAYS use fresh herbs and double the amount when using fresh!  Fresh herbs make a huge difference!  I also throw in dried cherries along with the dried cranberries.  Best stuffing I've ever had, my family can't wait for special occasions so Mom will break out the stuffing!  YUM!!

userID:
12437547
Display Name:
bluebelle
isPro:
False
followersCount:

madeRecipesCount:
21
favoritesCount:
397
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6056119.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum!! I used gluten free bread to suit dietary restrictions. You can't find boxed gluten free stuffing anywhere and it sucks to have to miss out on stuffing. The stock made it moist and you couldn't tell the difference. Even non gluten free people loved it. I left out the liver, used chicken stock as I couldn't find turkey, and threw in a handful of raisins as well. I baked it in a buttered baking dish at 350 for about an hour, so I didn't toast the bread cubes first. Stir it up halfway thru and be sure to cover it with foil so it won't dry out. You can take the foil off for the last ten mins or so just to give it a little bit of crisp on top if you want. The smell of it was delish. Next time I may try adding a beaten egg to help keep it all together. I will definitely be making this again next year. Thank you!

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

Allrecipes is turning me into quite the chef thanks to recipes like this.  I stuff the turkey with this because it's too difficult for me to multitask and time everything just right to be ready at the same time.

It's hard to find turkey stock anywhere so I use chicken and haven't received complaints.  My family loves this and it's a big family with a lot of different tastes and opinions.  They're surprised and amazed I can cook without giving everyone food poisoning but if you follow the recipe as stated you'll get perfect stuffing everytime.  

I have made it with both fresh herbs and dry and fresh gives more aroma but really, unless everyone is watching you and they have restaurant critic taste buds, give yourself a break and use whatever is handy!

Display Name:
Stef Van Camp

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become a staple in my house for Thanksgiving.  I've found myself year after year searching for the recipe, and this one is the closest to the one I was given the first year that I made it.  A few things that I've adjusted:  1 granny smith apple, one pear, and tossing in about 1/2 of a cup of fresh cranberries really gives the flavor an added depth that is just delicious.  I always use only sourdough bread-- a favorite in my house-- and I use fresh herbs, following the ratios in this recipe but adjusting for personal taste.  Friends and family agree-- best stuffing ever.

A few other adjustments that I make personally, based on my preference (the recipe itself is awesome, but I prefer using some of my own "tricks" to make it perfect for my taste):

Add more broth
Use Bob Evans brand or Jimmy Dean sausage
bake stuffing in a dutch oven (gives flavors a chance to meld, and makes it more like stuffing that came out of the turkey)
Add some all purpose seasoning to the bread, such as Adobo

This recipe is phenomenal-- If you're unsure whether or not you'll like it or you don't quite trust your cooking/baking talents yet... Give it a try-- Super easy, and you definitly won't be disappointed!

text:
Made this for Thanksgiving, when I couldn't find my favorite Thanksgiving stuffing recipe.  So glad, because now I have a new favorite!  This was perfect,  followed recipe, but I did substitute fresh  herbs (double the recipe for fresh) and cooked in the slow cooker as I didn't want to stuff the turkey, but I wanted a moist dressing.  It came out perfectly!  I simply put the stuffing together, added a bit of the stock and put in slow cooker on high for 45 minutes and low for 2 hours.  After about an hour, I stirred the stuffing and added a bit more stock. I have found  checking and adding stock to reach  your desired consistency in best. It was a very flavorful and easy dish.

text:
I did make some changes to this recipe using  some suggestions from other reviews as well as some of my own substitutions and absolutely loved the results!   I used a bagged sourdough dressing/stuffing mix, pork sausage, omitted the rosemary (not a big fan ),  used fresh sage and thyme, used dried parsley (stores were out of fresh), omitted the turkey livers and added about 2.5 cups of chicken broth since I baked it separately in dish. I stirred it to moisten the top bread cubes after baking at 350 F for 45 minutes covered and 15 minutes uncovered. My kids didn't care for the cranberries but everyone else loved it. I will definitely be making this again and might try adding an egg or two to bind/moisten it more (was planning to this time but forgot).

text:
I've never made stuffing, but wanted to try my hand at it for my boyfriend's family's gathering.  Boyfriend told me on the way up, "I didn't mention this before, but I'm really not a stuffing fan.  Sorry, babe."  Well, of course I made him try it, and he LOVED IT!  They all did!!  It was such a hit, I went home and made it again for my family's gathering tomorrow.  
---
I followed the recipe, except I omitted the turkey liver and substituted turkey stock for chicken stock (we had ham) and  used all fresh herbs except for the sage (it was sold out citywide!!) so I used dried rubbed sage instead.  Added the extra cup of stock which would've been sorely missed.  I used a very thick, hearty whole wheat bread (sliced) and a sourdough baguette for the white which made it less mushy.

text:
I've been making this stuffing for years now and LOVE IT! I always prep the day before Thanksgiving which makes it a breeze to put together in the mayhem. I use a crusty sourdough and Dave's Killer Bread (Good Seed). I cook the sage sausage, celery and onions and then add the apples, fresh herbs and cranberries and refrigerate the mixture over night. The flavors combine and in the morning, just combine with your bread cubes, stock and butter. DELISH!

text:
I used 1/2 lb of ground bacon & 1/2 lb of ground chicken instead of sausage.  I cooked ground bacon a bit, then added the onion, cooked it a bit more then added the chicken.  I used 1/2 cup of tart dried cherries & 1/2 cup of tart dried apricots chopped.  I chopped gala apple and  a little more broth.  I used the rest of the ingredients and put it all together the day before, then baked it separately in the oven for about an hour.  It was a huge hit with everyone.

text:
Although this seemed like a lot of ingredients and steps, I was ready for something different.  I took a short cut using a large bag of seasoned mixed bread cubes, but still added the fresh herbs.  I prepared the day before and refrigerated.  Before baking I drizzled with chicken broth and began baking covered with tin foil.  For the last half of the baking I uncovered. This was a smash hit!  The only disappointment is that I had so little left over!!  Next time I will double the amount using muffin tins for the additional volume, bake and then freeze in freezer bags.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I took my first bite, I thought yuk! I was sooooo disappointed then I took another and another and the flavors started to kick in and oh boy was I in heaven. I added a little more cranberries than called for and chopped up a granny smith apple. I used fresh herbs, doubling the amount and utilized a good amount of chicken stock. I stirred the mixture occasionally while cooking and after 40 minutes covered at 350, I removed the covering and cooked for an additional 15 minutes. I used the spiciest turkey sausage I could find and added a little sage turkey sausage. Everyone thought this stuffing was quite tasty and did not notice spiciness. I made another batch of traditional stuffing just in case this didn't turn out well. I used the same sausage and Pepperidge Farms seasoned and cornbread stuffing in a bag. The consensus was the traditional stuffing was much spicier but still quite good. When it came time to take a plate home I hid my sausage/apple/cranberry stuffing and dished out the traditional lol. I will definitely make this again.

text:
Everyone loved this stuffing. Definitely a do again. Even the younger ones said they loved it. My changes: 
1 switched 2 TBL poultry seasoning for the Sage, Rosemary and Thyme  
2 switched 1 TBL dry parsley for the fresh parsley 
3 instead sourdough bread for white bread
4 cooked it in the slow cooker instead of in the turkey
5 used Granny Smith apples instead of golden delicious. 
Yummy yum!

text:
I've made this as is and it wasn't very good.  - I'd give it 2 stars (too much of a bad sausage taste, the liver was just a bad idea to begin with and the apples made it too tart combined with the cranberries) but I thought it had a good thought process behind it.  So the next time I made it I used Jimmy Dean sage breakfast sausage, took out the apples and liver, used a little less cranberries, added a small can of drained chopped mushrooms and a bunch of chopped pecans.  Maybe I changed it too drastically to actually rate the second version as this version, but the second version I thought was way better - especially with the breakfast sausage.  But I've always used recipes more as a guide than as written in stone.

First time trying this recipe, but I ended up kicking it up a notch by using a mixture of green onion sausage and ground pork sausage.  All other ingredients were pretty much kept the same! Some ingredients (like the seasonings: onion celery, garlic) were adjusted for personal tastes)! The dressing turned out AWESOME! I was hesitant, at first, adding the apples,  despite all the favorable reviews, but I'm glad I did. It's the flavorful combination of the sausage, cranberries, and the apples that will absolutely drive your tastebuds insane, and your guests coming back for more!!

text:
YUM YUM YUM

I used a mix of seasoned premade crumbs and non-seasoned crumbs i made in the oven and therefore used slightly less in the seasoning department, but the stuffing was packed with flavor.  I used delicious Jimmy Dean sage sausage.  I added an egg and a cup of broth (very moist; I might use a 1/4 less next time).  I used regular cranberries (slightly reduced the amount) and added a splash of craisins.   I put foil over the stuffing and cooked for 30 minutes.  Stirred.  Cooked 15 minutes more.  Stirred and took off the foil.  Cooked 15 minutes more.  So delicious; thanks for making me Chef-like!!

userID:

Display Name:
Carlena Owenby
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2873248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a Thanksgiving potluck at work. I used an entire [large] loaf of whole wheat bread, because it is what I had. I added extra bread that what is called for, because the meat/bread ratio seems a bit off for stuffing. I used turkey sausage [italian] as suggested. For something a bit more traditional, this could be omitted. I'm not a huge fan of sausage, but I have to say this stuffing is pretty good!

If I made this again, I would add cornbread cubes, less meat, and less sage. 

For those of you who want to make this in a pan instead of stuffed in a turkey: [for the changes I made, using more bread cubes] I added a total of 2.5 cups of chicken stock to the pan once I had all the ingredients in. Baked covered for 30 minutes and about 15-20 minutes uncovered. Keep checking it after you uncover it. I stirred it up 1/2 way through the uncovered cooking process.] Spoon it into a serving dish, and voila!

text:
Just made this yesterday for a pre thanksgiving work dinner and it was delicious!! At first I was a little hesitant but once I tried it it was like an explosion of flavor in my mouth. I used some spicy turkey sausage for an extra kick and some mild. I put it in the oven for 45 minutes covered. I also used some undated and some salted chicken stock to guarantee it would not be salty and added extra to make sure it was not dry. I also reduced the onion a bit, I made this for 30 servings, it took me about 2 1/2 hours from start to finish. I never liked stuffing or dressing before because I tried before the ones with cornbread but this was delish!  Definetly recommended and will be making it again!

text:
A vivid, beautiful stuffing!  I did however, improvise. I made a recipe and a half but used 1lb. of sausage, all fresh herbs and more stock and butter than the recipe called for to ensure that it would come out moist. I also highly recommend using sage sausage to keep the flavors consistent. I also had to improvise the baking because I didn't use it in the turkey. I baked it covered, at 350 for 20 minutes then took the cover off for 5. I will surely make it again.

text:
My family wasn't wild about stuffing until I found this recipe 9 years ago. Now everyone requests it including my kids spouses! I made a few modifications over the years. I use maple sausage and store bought unseasoned cornbread stuffing. I also add pecans pieces (or bits - whichever is handy) for a little bit of a different texture. My family doesn't like the liver in it so I do leave that out. I use plenty of liquid to keep it moist. I also always make extra since somebody always wants to take some home.

text:
Everyone at Christmas dinner said they loved this even though I wasn't too impressed.  I used spicy turkey sausage but I think I'll try to find sage flavored sausage next time.  It was better the next day in my turkey sandwich.  If you don't have day old bread, just buy croutons and it would work the same and probably would be easier by skipping that first step.  Roughly chop the apples as I diced and thought the taste of the apples was lost.  Craisins were a great addition.  Bon appetite!

I will definitely be keeping this recipe and use it every year for Thanksgiving as it was a hit!

text:
Followed the exact recipe minus the turkey liver. Assembled all the dry ingredients in a large bowl beforehand and refrigerated. Later, transferred mixture to a large corningware dish, added butter and broth and placed in oven. Cooked 30 minutes, then stirred and drizzled an X of chicken broth on top. Cooked for 20 more minutes.  Easy to make and everyone loved it. Will definitely make again!

userID:
1839519
Display Name:
juno_lake
isPro:

followersCount:
3

58

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/395044.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
it was good, but very busy. I ike stuffing to be more savory and this was pretty fruity. It wasn't bad, just different. Got plenty of complements on it too. The only change I made was to omit the celery, and add some nuts instead. I will probably not add nuts next time. One other reviewer mentioned preassembing the stuffing the night before. That worked well by only assembling the dry items and adding the wet ingredients right before putting it into the oven. 350 for 1 hour seems to work well if cooking it separately from the turkey. Be prepared to add extra stock if it seems like it needs it during the cooking. I covered mine, which helped to reserve liquids while cooking and uncovered it for the last 15 min. DON'T SKIP THE SAUSAGE (it adds savory flavor) and try to find the flavored sausage, too. I used fresh herbs, and likely will again. Be sure to double the amount for fresh herbs. I will likely make it again, thanks for sharing.

text:
Awesome!  I had the best Thanksgiving this year thanks to some of the best recipes on this site!  I did have to make a few minor changes because I went to Stater Brothers this year and they didn't carry turkey sausage or turkey stock (strange, huh?!).  I used pork sausage (a little greasy, definitely use turkey sausage) and chicken stock.  I omitted the turkey liver, but other than that, I followed the recipe by the letter and everyone loved it!  I baked it in the oven instead of filling the turkey like other reviewers and it turned out great.  I probably added too much stock because I didn't want it dry, so next year I'll put in the amount that the recipe calls for and adjust as needed.  I'd use fresh herbs instead of dry and a granny smith apple next year, but otherwise... it really is an AWESOME recipe! :)  Thanks!!!!!

text:
As far as "non traditional" stuffing goes - this one is awesome! I had to use chicken liver instead of turkey and spicy sausage instead of regular which actually added a lot of flavor. Other than that, and the fact that I didn't place the mixture in the bird but rather in a baking dish in the over for 15 minutes, everything was done as the recipe called. Next time I will add mroe apples, which added a nice crunch along with the celery. Great recipe that I will use again!

text:
Great recipe with all of the changes that I made.  I doubled the recipe for a party of 20, and it was all gone! You have to take into consideration that my family isn't big on stuffing but they enjoyed it a lot. The changes that I made were toasting the bread pieces a few more minutes than called for until they were fully crisp.  I also did not add the cooked liver because it wouldn't suit some of my guests.  I also used hot and mild Italian sausage.  Next time, I would use less chicken stock because it was a bit too mushy for my personal liking.  To top it off, I used one golden delicious apple and one green apple, and it was perfect!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I basically kept the recipe "as is" but doubled it and cooked it separately from the bird. The doubled recipe took about 45 min at 375 degrees in a tightly foiled 2-qt buttered baking dish. It was fabulous. I didn't take off the foil at the end, but if you wanted it crispy on the top, you could just remove the foil during the last 15 min of baking time. The only changes I made were: used pork sausage, made my own bread to use (a white bread with sage & rosemary), and allowed the bread to air dry for 36 hrs instead of simply toasting it. This will definitely be on the menu again.

I made this for my first official Thanksgiving dinner, just a few days ago.  Although this seemed like a lot of prep work, it really paid off! BUNSY

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good, and I did receive complements on it. Due to time constraints, I used a box of pre-seasoned stuffing bread instead of toasting my own bread. It worked out ok, but I think it would have tasted better with freshly toasted bread, as the pre-seasoned stuff introduced a strong competing flavor. Other modifications I made were:  decreased the amount of sausage (because we were already eating it with turkey). The type of sausage I used was "Jenny-O Turkey Breakfast Sausage Links", and I just squeezed the ground sausage out of the casings and broke it up in the pan. I also used Granny Smith apples because I prefer a more crisp and tart flavor over the mushy Golden Delicious. And, I increased amount to 2 apples. I also used fresh herbs, and increased the amount of stock because I baked it outside the turkey in a casserole dish (as suggested by others). Next time, I will definitely toast my own bread like the recipe calls for.  But, if you are short on time and decide to use boxed stuffing -- my advice is to make sure that it is NOT pre-seasoned, as the flavor will be off.

userID:
3294389
Display Name:
DinnersON
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
14
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an excellent change from my traditional family's stuffing. I served 8 guests and got a thumbs up from 7 out 8 people. I followed other's advice and it turned out great! Here are my following notes: I changed the amount of servings to 30 which yielded one 9x13 casserole and one 8x8 casserole. This way everyone was sent home with extra's. 1. I used a one lb. loaf of plain stuffing bread, one round loaf of sourdough, and a one lb. loaf of wheat, which I dried out days before and stored in a airtight container. 
2. 2 pounds Jimmy Dean mild pork sausage instead of 3 for the caculated 30 servings
3. two golden delicious and one fuji apple (grated in a hand grater)
4. 1-1/2 cups of dried craisans (cut in smaller pieces)
5. doubled all the herbs (used fresh)
6. 5 cups chicken stock
7.**added one egg beaten in stock before mixing
8. baked 350 degrees in buttered casseroles as mentioned for about 40 minutes covered with foil then remove for 15 to brown. 
**If I was to make again I would probably decreased the craisans by another 1/2 cup (my preference since the craisans are very bold and tart).
I'm not sure I would make this every Thanksgiving since are family is not used to a sweet stuffing but, it is definately worth the five stars!

5

text:
This was UNBELIEVABLE! I am a vegetarian, so I made a couple of adjustments. I used a baguette that was freshly baked at the local grocery story, and ommited the liver. I used soy protein sausage (SO GOOD), and couldn't afford all of the fresh herbs, so I used some rosemary and thyme "icecubes" that I had made from my fresh herb plants this past summer. I did splurge and buy the fresh parsley. Since I didn't put it in the turkey, I used a little over a cup of veggie stock, popped it in a greased pan, and cooked it for an hour at 350. It came out PERFECT. The only change I would make for next time - break up the bread a little smaller and maybe add another apple. SO GOOD!!

text:
Learn from my mistake!  If you are using turkey sausage with the skin, best to cut up the skin first, or wait until the sausage is completely cooked then chop it up into smaller bits.  Our sausage chunks were too big and it overwhelmed the stuffing.  Hope to make this again with better results.  As for now, I'm afraid stove top beat this one.

text:
Ohmygoodness!  With much trepidation, I broke tradition this year and tried this recipe instead of our usual cake-like mushy dressing/stuffing.  It was a HIT!  Several of the kids & teens who usually turn up their noses at this side dish gobbled it up. Per previous reviews, I omitted the liver, doubled the spices and put it in an oven-proof dish and baked it in the oven on 250 for 40min, stirring twice. This will be our go-to dressing/stuffing recipe for the next thirty years. THANKS!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to stuffing.  I'm living in Ukraine now, so I've had to alter things a little, but the best thing I've done is use a chicken sausage, despite the insistence in many comments to use pork sausage.  It reduces the fat content of this stuffing without sacrificing the flavours, and it stays in the poultry theme.  I'd use turkey sausage if I could (and I have).  Jimmy Dean products are full of fillers and are generally ridiculously high in fat.  I also stick with dried cranberries, as Craisins are sweetened, and the extra sugar is unnecessary.

text:
Happy Holidays! This is the BEST stuffing recipe and very easy to make.  I made it for a Christmas party and also for our family dinner and it was a hit. The only changes I made were using pork sausage (couldn't find turkey) and left out the turkey neck. Oh, and I used fresh herbs along with a dash of dried poultry seasoning. I also used an egg to help bind. I cooked mine in a crock pot and it was perfect. I will definitely be making this next year!!!

This stuffing was very good. Quite the crown pleaser. I made it for Thanksgiving and even the people who don't normally like stuffing tried it and liked it. I didn't put it in the bird because it dries out the meat. So, I used some extra chicken stock to make it a little more moist. I also didn't use the liver. So, I used a full pound of turkey sausage. It came out pretty good. Still a little dry, so I might use even more chicken stock this time.

text:
This stuffing is delicious!!! I followed the advice of others and used fresh herbs...amazing. I also used sourdough bread which I purchased fresh and just let it sit out of a day. I also used pork sausage instead of the turkey. I think it gave it more flavor. I omitted the turkey liver and used a granny smith since that's what I had. Oh, I also added an egg as others suggested to hold it together better. The only change I will make in the future is to use more bread. I like the mushiness of stuffing. I found there to be a lot of other "things" and not enough bread...but the taste is fantastic!!!

text:
I made this for Thanksgiving and for those who actually eat stuffing, they loved it!  It was very easy to make and I didn't make the bread stuffing myself, I used Mrs. Cubbison's seasoned dressing by  mistake(I meant to buy the seasoned stuffing).  The dressing is almost more like crumbs then stuffing mix, but it didn't matter, it was still delicious.  I didn't follow the amount of stock in the recipe, I kept adding stock til it was moist enough to my liking. You can use whatever apples you have handy, I chose to use the Granny Smith apple because the dried cranberry already has a little sweetness to it.   I used a Jimmy Dean sausage instead but it is definitely a part of this recipe that can be played with, so being that there are a lot of sausages out there, next time I will try a different sausage.  This is definitely a recipe I will make again.

text:
My family and I aren't big stuffing fans, but my husband and his family are, so I had to find a good recipe for Thanksgiving dinner. I've never in my life made stuffing, so I was a little worried... I didn't know what it was supposed to look like or taste like, so I just followed this recipe and my husband and his family raved about it! I followed the recipe almost exactly, however, I omitted the Turkey Liver and added half a pack of Jimmy Deans Sage Sausage... since the sausage already contained sage, I didn't add any extra, also I used Chicken stock instead of Turkey stock.... and last, when I cooked all the meat, it looked like way too much meat so I ended up taking some out. I never tasted the stuffing, but everyone else gave it 5 stars.

text:
Wonderful recipe!  Growing up I either had the stuffing that came in a box, or else home made stuffing that was almost bitter tasting!  Either way, the great thing about this recipe is that you can actually tell what your eating.  Its colorful and all the flavors mix so well.  I cooked our Thanksgiving dinner for the first time and this will be passed through our family for sure and will be a holiday hit for generations to come!  I couldnt find the gizzard bag in our turkey, so I left out the turkey liver and it was still wonderful.  Maybe Christmas I will put in the liver, but its still great without!  A must try recipe!  I deep fried my turkey so I cooked this in a casserole dish with a lid at 350 for about 45 min.

text:
We felt there was a bit too much sausage. Maybe if I'd cubed up the bread smaller.. I don't know. It was still REEEEALLY good, had a great flavor. I'd probably cut the sausage in 1/2 next time. 
Also, I made it outside the turkey while the turkey was resting. I used drippings from the turkey (which I had plenty of since I used the Turkey Brine & Homestyle Turkey, the Michigander Way from this site) to moisten it. Baked at 350 for about an hour, pouring additional drippings over and mixing when I felt it needed it. Thanks for this one.. I'll be making it again!

text:
Perfect recipe!  I followed others' suggestions as follows: omitted the turkey liver, used an egg to hold it together.  I also made this mostly the night before Thanksgiving.  I cooked the sausage, toasted the bread and put the sausage/onion/spices mixture over the bread all the night before.  I put everything in a greased baking dish and sprayed olive oil over it all.  The next day, I added the rest of the ingredients, covered it with foil and cooked it on 350 for about 45 min.  I ended up almost doubling the chicken stock.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
This stuffing is wonderful!  I used reduced fat pork sausage (couldn't find turkey sausage).  I also added about a cup of chicken broth, since I cooked it outside the turkey.  Also, I kept checking it while it cooked (approx 1/2 hour), and added more broth as needed.
Growing up, we always used the dried stuffing cubes.  Well,  my family loved this!  The texture was perfect.  I will definitely make this one again.  So easy!

text:
Stacy thank you for this reciepe..... I did take beaten egg whites and brush the top.  Followed recciepe to the T.  Stacy you could of never shared and made a million with this Thank you.  Family loves it year after year.  Egg white brush gives such a nice look will take a picture and share.  Another saving step I take is I brown the sausage, onion celery mix freeze in freezer then assemble the night before and pour butter and home made turkey broth over.  Find a church that feeds the homeless and you will have the best broth.  Plus I start in November saving the best bread left overs and dry them out.  It seems like a lot of work but it is so easy to do it in steps.

I found this recipe when planning Thanksgiving dinner and just HAD to make it.  I went in search of a turkey stock recipe and found that Stacy provided that as well.  See Awesome Turkey Giblet Stock on this site.  It is easy to make and delicious.  I also used the extra stock for my gravy.  The only thing I changed was adding a half pound of Jimmy Dean Sage Sausage when I cooked the turkey sausage and onion, and leaving out the turkey liver, as suggested in earlier postings.

userID:

Display Name:
SMASON39
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my second year in a row for this stuffing and forget the turkey, I can't stop picking at the leftovers of this stuffing!!! My changes this year were to add some fresh garlic and portobello mushrooms (in lieu of liver) to the sausage/veg mixture, added some pepper to the spices, and used less butter but added some white wine. I also didn't stuff this in the bird but cooked it in a casserole for 30 minutes and gave it several baster squirts of turkey juice for flavor and moisture throughout the cooking. Also, though I like the texture of the toasted breads I also tore up and added a few pieces of non-toasted bread so that I could have a mixture of soft and toasted breads in the stuffing. One last thing--I recommend a tart crisp apple like Empire or Granny Smith.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

This is definitely a recipe that will be used at Christmas too.

text:
This was very good and my husband who doesn't like stuffing said this was good--which is the ultimate compliment.  My 7 and 3 year old would not touch--thinks it may be a little fancy for some little ones.  I did not add the liver, added a LOT more broth which you will definitely need to do if you like your stuffing moist and I baked early in the day--let the flavors meld and just reheated for dinner. Not difficult at all to make and very dellicious--just remember to add more broth if you don't like dry stuffing! :)Thanks for a very good recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This stuffing is so yummy!  Usually I load everything with gravy, but this tasted so good I didn't want to ruin the flavor.  Per other reviews, I used a Granny Smith apple, sourdough and wheat breads. I did not stuff the turkey, and since I didn't have any room in the oven, I cooked this on the stove.  If you cook it stovetop, there's no need to add extra liquid (I put in a cup of vegetable broth instead of turkey stock since my turkey was still baking)--mine was a bit on the wet side (I left it on low on the stove for quite a while to try to dry it out as much as possible).  I had an unplanned variation since I did not have Sage on hand--my substitution was some Italian Seasoning since it has some Sage in it.  I will definitely make this stuffing again (but I'll make sure there's Sage in my cabinet)!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6019103.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great start of a recipe, but only 4 stars since I change it up to suit our tastes.  First, I never, ever stuff the turkey - it is only used as a dressing, so the moisture has to be adjusted.  I use part corn bread (not the sweet kind) instead of all bread and then adjust the seasonings for our taste.  I add more broth - this is where corn bread works better than all wheat/white bread because it doesn't "break down" like the other breads when it gets moistened.  A tart apple is the only way to go, so I use a Granny Smith.  Fabulous with any dried fruit you like - I've made it with cranberries, cherries, blueberries and combinations of various fruits.  I prefer the flavor of a hot Italian sausage instead of a turkey sausage.
Review:

5

I moved to England a few years ago and started celebrating Thanksgiving with our friends here.  I used this recipe last year and everyone LOVED it...even my very picky Irish in-laws! It has been requested again this year by all of my guests.  Excellent recipe!

text:
Since I started "doing" Thanksgiving at my house I have more flexibility in what is served.  I make 2 stuffings, The stand by traditional homemade bread stuffing and a "different" kind.  I love stuffing.  So last thanksgiving I made this one because of all the rave reviews.  I followed the recipe to a t but it was kinda gross.  No one ate seconds.  We actually had to throw the left overs of this stuffing out.  Never happens.  I think my brother liked it though.  I don't believe I will make this again.  Like another reviewer said you will either love it or hate it.  I will still continue looking for another stuffing and make my grandmas traditional stuffing as well.
